title: NameError: Exception encountered when calling layer "lambda_1" (type Lambda).
body:
`if __name__ == "__main__":
    (x_train, y_train, groups_train), (x_test, y_test, groups_test) = load_data()
    
    model = load_model(os.path.join("/content/drive/MyDrive/models", "model.h5"))
    model.summary()

    print("training:")
    y_true, y_pred = y_train, np.argmax(model.predict(x_train, batch_size=1024, verbose=1), axis=-1)

    C = confusion_matrix(y_true, y_pred, labels=(1, 0))
    TP, TN, FP, FN = C[0, 0], C[1, 1], C[1, 0], C[0, 1]
    acc, sn, sp = 1. * (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN), 1. * TP / (TP + FN), 1. * TN / (TN + FP)
    print("acc: {}, sn: {}, sp: {}".format(acc, sn, sp))

    print("testing:")
    y_true, y_pred = y_test, np.argmax(model.predict(x_test, batch_size=1024, verbose=1), axis=-1)

    C = confusion_matrix(y_true, y_pred, labels=(1, 0))
    TP, TN, FP, FN = C[0, 0], C[1, 1], C[1, 0], C[0, 1]
    acc, sn, sp = 1. * (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN), 1. * TP / (TP + FN), 1. * TN / (TN + FP)
    print("acc: {}, sn: {}, sp: {}".format(acc, sn, sp))`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/86849708/151673124-81fbe818-87c8-4285-b1db-e944da943eca.png)
comments: @izainpasha can you please elaborate your issue?

@izainpasha ,
In order to expedite the trouble-shooting process, could you please provide a minimal code snippet and the TensorFlow version you are using.Also please try to execute the code with full code by following indentation and naming conventions.It helps.Thanks!
Looks like the error is due to providing wrong naming conventions.Thanks!

> @izainpasha , In order to expedite the trouble-shooting process, could you please provide a minimal code snippet and the TensorFlow version you are using.Also please try to execute the code with full code by following indentation and naming conventions.It helps.Thanks!

import pickle

import numpy as np
import os
from keras.models import load_model
from scipy.interpolate import splev, splrep
from sklearn.metrics import confusion_matrix

base_dir = "dataset"

ir = 3
before = 2
after = 2

# normalize
scaler = lambda arr: (arr - np.min(arr)) / (np.max(arr) - np.min(arr))


def load_data():
    tm = np.arange(0, (before + 1 + after) * 60, step=1 / float(ir))

    with open(os.path.join(base_dir, "apnea-ecg.pkl"), 'rb') as f:
        apnea_ecg = pickle.load(f)

    x_train = []
    o_train, y_train = apnea_ecg["o_train"], apnea_ecg["y_train"]
    groups_train = apnea_ecg["groups_train"]
    for i in range(len(o_train)):
        (rri_tm, rri_signal), (ampl_tm, ampl_siganl) = o_train[i]
        rri_interp_signal = splev(tm, splrep(rri_tm, scaler(rri_signal), k=3), ext=1)
        ampl_interp_signal = splev(tm, splrep(ampl_tm, scaler(ampl_siganl), k=3), ext=1)
        x_train.append([rri_interp_signal, ampl_interp_signal])
    x_train = np.array(x_train, dtype="float32").transpose((0, 2, 1))
    y_train = np.array(y_train, dtype="float32")

    x_test = []
    o_test, y_test = apnea_ecg["o_test"], apnea_ecg["y_test"]
    groups_test = apnea_ecg["groups_test"]
    for i in range(len(o_test)):
        (rri_tm, rri_signal), (ampl_tm, ampl_siganl) = o_test[i]
        rri_interp_signal = splev(tm, splrep(rri_tm, scaler(rri_signal), k=3), ext=1)
        ampl_interp_signal = splev(tm, splrep(ampl_tm, scaler(ampl_siganl), k=3), ext=1)
        x_test.append([rri_interp_signal, ampl_interp_signal])
    x_test = np.array(x_test, dtype="float32").transpose((0, 2, 1))
    y_test = np.array(y_test, dtype="float32")

    return (x_train, y_train, groups_train), (x_test, y_test, groups_test)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    (x_train, y_train, groups_train), (x_test, y_test, groups_test) = load_data()

    model = load_model(os.path.join("./models", "model.final.h5"))
    model.summary()

    print("training:")
    y_true, y_pred = y_train, np.argmax(model.predict(x_train, batch_size=1024, verbose=1), axis=-1)

    C = confusion_matrix(y_true, y_pred, labels=(1, 0))
    TP, TN, FP, FN = C[0, 0], C[1, 1], C[1, 0], C[0, 1]
    acc, sn, sp = 1. * (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN), 1. * TP / (TP + FN), 1. * TN / (TN + FP)
    print("acc: {}, sn: {}, sp: {}".format(acc, sn, sp))

    print("testing:")
    y_true, y_pred = y_test, np.argmax(model.predict(x_test, batch_size=1024, verbose=1), axis=-1)

    C = confusion_matrix(y_true, y_pred, labels=(1, 0))
    TP, TN, FP, FN = C[0, 0], C[1, 1], C[1, 0], C[0, 1]
    acc, sn, sp = 1. * (TP + TN) / (TP + TN + FP + FN), 1. * TP / (TP + FN), 1. * TN / (TN + FP)
    print("acc: {}, sn: {}, sp: {}".format(acc, sn, sp))

Here is the full Code snippet I've my trained model saved in drive and the Tensorflow is 1.15.2

> error is due to providing wrong naming

Can you please check where the issue is? Cause I've rewrite it several times and can't find where the naming issue

> @izainpasha can you please elaborate your issue?

I'm trying to load my model but it is showing nameerror of K that haven't been used in the whole code

@izainpasha ,
We see that you are using tf version 1.15, 1.x is not actively supported, please update to latest stable v2.7 and let us know if you are facing same issue.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has no recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you.
Closing as stale. Please reopen if you'd like to work on this further.
Are you satisfied with the resolution of your issue? Yes No

title: [ROCm] Fix to enable TFRT BEF Thunk unit tests to pass on ROCm.
body:
In order to get the //tensorflow/compiler/xla/service/gpu/tests:mlir_gemm_test unit test to work on ROCm, this fix is needed.

There are other fixes that are needed in TFRT itself, but this is needed for Tensorflow.

/cc @chsigg @hanbinyoon
comments:
> I find it surprising that you need to add dependencies to `tf_to_kernel`. That is a tool to aot-compile GPU kernels using MLIR (instead of Eigen) and is unrelated to BEF thunks. Could you elaborate why it's needed?

If I build without this change, when the linker builds tf_to_kernel (as a result of BEF thunk), it complains that it can't find the reference to some platform specific symbol (don't remember what it is) so the only way that I could resolve this is by adding the appropriate dependency as shown in this PR.

However, your point is well taken.  It is strange that for CUDA, this change is apparently unnecessary.

One thing is that when I used bazel to trace dependencies, the ROCM stream executor did not appear.  So for CUDA, the CUDA stream executor dependency is apparently getting specified some other way.
Could you please use [`bazel cquery`](https://docs.bazel.build/versions/main/cquery.html) to figure out why this dependency is needed?
yep.  doing exactly that ATM.
Using bazel cquery, I was able to implement a better, more targeted fix.  I reverted the previous change.  The linker error was directly related to asm_compiler.

title: [TF-TRT] Adding CSV export to Detailed Non Conversion Report
body:
@bixia1 for review

`TF_TRT_SHOW_DETAILED_REPORT` triggers three possible behaviors:

- **If Number >= 1:**      Print detailed non-conversion report on stdout.
                                      *Usage: `TF_TRT_SHOW_DETAILED_REPORT=1`*
                                 
- **If non empty string:** Exports the non-conversion report in CSV format at
                                       the path defined by the environment variable.
                                       This will also print the detailed non-conversion
                                       report on stdout.
                                       *Usage: `TF_TRT_SHOW_DETAILED_REPORT=/path/to/file.csv`*
                                  
- **Else:**                        Print normal (undetailed) non-conversion report on stdout.
comments: @bixia1 : comment fixed, let me know if we need anything else
@bixia1 comments have been addressed. Can you approve ?

title: AttributeError: 'float' object has no attribute 'dtype',  When executing tfp.optimizer.differential_evolution_one_step
body:
This error is shown whenever tf.optimizer.differential_evolution_one_step is called.

This error is due to line 125 in the tensorflow optimizer file differential_evolution.py, which is,
crossover_prob=0.9

In this line, the variable crossover_prob is given as a float whereas it is required to be a tensorflow variable later in the file on line 652, which is,
dtype=crossover_prob.dtype.base_dtype,

changing crossover_prob to a tf.Variable before line 652 will solve this problem.
Also, setting the default value of crossover_prob in line 125 from
crossover_prob=0.9, to
crossover_prob=tf.Variable(0.9)
will also solve this problem and allow for this function to run.

Thank you

title: Implementation of converters for unary operators "Round" and "Sign"
body:
Converters and corresponding tests for unary operators "Round" and "Sign" were implemented.
Since the Myelin support for these operators in implicit batch mode has not yet been merged, I've added some checks to prevent these converters from being used and tested in this mode.
PR#54181:Implementation of converters for unary operators "Round" and "Sign"
NOTE: This PR should be slightly adjusted if it will be merged after
[PR#54230:](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/pull/54230): **Refactoring of ConvertUnary**

title: ImportError: cannot import name 'Bidirectional' from 'tensorflow.python.keras.layers' (tf-nightly)
body:
**System information**
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): Windows 10
- Mobile device (e.g. iPhone 8, Pixel 2, Samsung Galaxy) if the issue happens on mobile device: n/a
- TensorFlow installed from (source or binary): pip
- TensorFlow version: tf-nightly 2.9.0.dev20220127
- Python version: 3.10.2
- Installed using virtualenv? pip? conda?: pip
- Bazel version (if compiling from source): n/a
- GCC/Compiler version (if compiling from source): n/a
- CUDA/cuDNN version: n/a
- GPU model and memory: n/a

**Describe the problem**
I'm using the following import statement:

`from tensorflow.python.keras.layers import LSTM, Dense, Dropout, Bidirectional`

which ends up with the following error when I run the script

ImportError: cannot import name 'Bidirectional' from 'tensorflow.python.keras.layers' (C:\Python310\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\python\keras\layers\__init__.py)

I'm using VS Code and as such the import resolves just fine. I had to change the import line from
`tensorflow.keras.layers` to `tensorflow.python.keras.layers` though.

Am I doing something wrong here or is it an issue with tf-nightly and win10/python 3.10?
comments: @sushreebarsa better? At this point I am not really sure if this should be reported as a bug or a build/install issue or  general support. Enlighten me please :-)

@Mhbuur Could you please try with the latest TF v2.7.0 and refer to [build from source](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/source_windows) , [tested build configurations](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/source_windows#tested_build_configurations) ? Please find the colab [gist](https://colab.research.google.com/gist/sushreebarsa/e59f95fa9601131fbe9eed33ff2811bd/untitled551.ipynb#scrollTo=F-A5eL_ntWKA) for reference and let us know if it helps?Thanks!
@sushreebarsa Python 3.10 is not supported in TF 2.7.0, which is why I'm trying out 2.9 / tf-nightly
@Mhbuur Please see the discussion on [TF Forum ](https://discuss.tensorflow.org/t/support-python-3-10/124?u=mihaimaruseac).Thanks!
@sushreebarsa thanks. I am aware of that discussion - it got me started on tf-nightly ;-) Should I report there instead?

@sushreebarsa how do you get hold of tf-nightly version 2.9.0.dev20220131? 
When I update or install using --no-cache param (after uninstalling) I keep getting tf_nightly 2.9.0.dev20220129
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/419020/151825547-d5a2e1e8-b350-4b0b-bef6-eed721015c57.png)

Regarding the import path: the only way I could get VS Code to resolve the import was to use the `tensorflow.python.keras.layers` path. If I use `tensorflow.keras.layers` it will not resolve:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/419020/151963376-2fff4e6b-e1e9-470a-8b54-c34d722345e5.png)
`Import "tensorflow.keras.layers" could not be resolved pylance (report MissingImports)`

Do you think this `tensorflow.python...` path is the cause for the first ImportError problem regarding 'Bidirectional'?

@sushreebarsa ok, there is some progress - after updating I can actually run the script (without the tensorflow.python path) - it still doesn't resolve in the IDE, but the script now runs without the bidirectional error. So either the update/reinstall fixed it or the import path change, I can't tell for sure.

The VS Code import path resolve issue is discussed many other places, so I'll close this issue for now.
Are you satisfied with the resolution of your issue? Yes No
@Mhbuur could you please post a link to a solution for "the VS Code import path resolve issue" if you found one?

SOLUTION: See [here](https://github.com/microsoft/pylance-release/issues/1066#issuecomment-1022431087). You may want to add other things like `layer`, `models`, `activations`, `regularizers`, `constraints`, etc.

This is so hacky though... Feels like the TensorFlow team should take a look at this.
@macoskey Yes, that was one of the suggestions I looked at. I didn't try it out as I found it a bit too hacky. But thanks for confirming that it works as a temporary measure.

title: Update version numbers for TensorFlow 2.5.3
body:
Before merging this PR, please double check that it has correctly updated
`core/public/version.h`, `tools/pip_package/setup.py`, and
`tensorflow/tensorflow.bzl`. Also review the execution notes below:

```
Major: 2 -> 2
Minor: 5 -> 5
Patch: 2 -> 3

No lingering old version strings "2.5.2" found in source directory 
"tensorflow/". Good.

"tensorflow/". Good.
```
